Award.AwardTitle: A self-assembled nano-array platform for membrane protein sensors and analytics

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1134222
Roper

Intellectual Merit: This NSF award by the Biosensing /CBET program supports work by Professors D. Keith Roper and Shannon Servoss at University of Arkansas is to self assemble a novel platform to detect and analyze membrane proteins. The platform consists of electromagnetically active arrays of nanorings in which lipid bilayers are stabilized by novel linkers to stabilize and test membrane proteins better than existing lipid vesicles. Electromagnetism interacting with concentrated electrons localized to the nanoring interface provides increased sensitivity relative to existing optical or electronic sensors. Supporting this study develops a sensitive, highthroughput platform to detect biomarkers to diagnose disease, test efficacy for therapeutic targets, and advance understanding of cell function.

Broader Impacts: This study will educate two graduate students in active bio/nano photonics and peptidomimetics in an integrative multidisciplinary environment to fabricate and analyze nano scale devices and biomaterials. Its social impact includes introducing underrepresented undergraduates to STEM research in NSF REU programs. Results will incorporated into workshops to introduce K-12 students to engineering in interactive, hands; on experiments as part of a program sponsored by the College of Engineering. Its economic impact arises from possible applications of self; assembled electromagnetic biomaterials that enhance single; molecule microscopy and biosensing and become next generation opto electronic elements in microarrays and near; field optical microscopy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of the completed research is two-fold: (1) peptoid functionalization of lipid bilayer discs and (2) development of nanoarray platforms for membrane protein sensors and analytics. Peptoids were incorporated into either the edges or the plane of lipid bilayer discs. Peptoid functionalization of lipid bilayer discs alters the surface chemistry, thereby making it possible to immobilize them to a surface for use in sensors and analytics. Such sensors and analytics can be used to investigate membrane-associated proteins and/or protein-protein interactions. In addition to the proposed application, peptoid-functionalized lipid bilayer discs also have utility in electrophoretic separation of proteins and for expression of membrane-associated proteins.

 

Sensing based on localized surface plasmons has been studied for over a decade. But progress has been limited due to lack of rapid, accurate theoretical descriptions that reveal fundamental physics of plasmon/sensing interactions. Substantial advances were made in theory (analytical, computational, and approximate solutions), fabrication (conventional top down and novel bottom up approaches), and characterization (opto electronic and microspectroscopy).  A new compact model that identified the physics underlying interactions involving plasmons on nanospheroids like toroids was awarded national recognition.  A novel, bottom-up method to assemble nanospheroids in biocompatible media for sensing was recognized on NSF’s website. These results (involving undergraduate and underrepresented students) integrated plasmon characterization and optical interactions at geometric and nano-scale dimensions on biocompatible sensors for membrane proteins for the first time. 

 

The broader impact of this work was realized through the training of undergraduate and graduate students as well as community outreach. This project trained five PhD students, three MS students, and four BS students. The PI organized the chemical engineering section of the Engineering Summer Academy, which hosted 25 high school students for a week-long, hands-on experience in the laboratory. The academy offers opportunities for students to perform chemical engineering research and better prepare them for future careers in engineering.
